awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Pilot Fiber Seismic Networks at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station
awd_abstract_narration:
This EAGER award will explore the Distributed Acoustic Sensing emerging technology that transforms a single optical fiber into a massively multichannel seismic array. This technology may provide a scalable and affordable way to deploy dense seismic networks. Experimental Distributed Acoustic Sensing equipment will be tested in the Antarctic exploiting unused (dark) strands in the existing fiber-optic cable that connects the U.S. Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station to the Remote Earth Science and Seismological Observatory (SPRESSO) located about 7.5-km from the main station. Upon processing the seismic signals, the Distributed Acoustic Sensing may provide a new tool to structurally image firn, glacial ice, and glacial bedrock. Learning how Distributed Acoustic Sensing would work on the ice sheet, scientists can then check seismological signals propagating through the Earth's crust and mantle variously using natural icequakes and earthquakes events in the surrounding area.

The investigators propose to convert at least 8 km of pre-existing fiber optic cable at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole station into more than 8000 sensors to explore the potential of Distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) as a breakthrough data engine for polar seismology. The DAS array will operate for about one year, allowing them to (1) evaluate and calibrate the performance of the DAS technology in the extreme cold, very low noise (including during the exceptionally quiet austral winter) polar plateau environment; (2) record and analyze local ambient and transient signals from ice, anthropogenic signals, ocean microseism, atmospheric and other processes, as well as to study local, regional, and teleseismic tectonic events; (3) structurally image the firn, glacial ice, glacial bed, crust, and mantle, variously using active sources, ambient seismic noise, and natural icequake and earthquake events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The EAGER project focused on establishing a pilot fiber seismic network at the Amundsen-Scott South Pole Station, demonstrating the potential of Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS) technology in one of the harshest environments on Earth. The fieldwork, which involved installing the DAS instrument in extreme cold, was a significant logistical and technical success. We achieved all fieldwork goals, including getting the DAS array up and running, and conducting active site surveys despite the challenging conditions. The DAS array operated continuously for two years without the need for maintenance, proving the scalability of DAS in cold environments and setting the stage for future DAS experiments in Antarctica.

Scientifically, the project met all its goals. We detected natural tectonic events on the relatively seismically quiet Antarctic continent and were able to locate them using a single DAS array, highlighting the effectiveness of DAS for earthquake detection and location. Additionally, we identified other types of seismic events, such as ice quakes and fern quakes, using an array with 4,000 sensors spaced two meters apart, providing an unprecedented level of detail in studying cryo-seismicity. Another major scientific achievement was the use of DAS to study glacier structures through active source seismology. By conducting an active seismic survey with a weight drop device, we obtained high-quality data that allowed us to image both shallow firn structures, which are crucial for estimating ice mass loss, and deeper glacier structures using reflections from the glacier base. Our observations confirmed that the glacier base near the South Pole is at melting temperature, a finding with significant implications for the stability and potential ice loss of the Antarctic ice sheet.

The continuous operation of DAS for two years not only allowed us to monitor seismicity but also enabled us to track changes in glacier structure over time. The high-resolution data showed that shallow glacier structures change by about 1% in response to temperature variations. This capability suggests that DAS could be a valuable tool for monitoring how glaciers respond to climate change in other regions. This project, intended as a pilot, successfully demonstrated the technology, established best practices for fieldwork, and developed data processing capabilities for applying DAS to polar seismology. The success of this project has convinced us of the great potential of DAS in cryoseismology and its broader applications in regions with critical science questions related to ice mass loss and global sea level rise.

The results of this project have been widely disseminated, presented at multiple academic conferences, and peer-reviewed journals. The project has also reached broader audiences through various online and in-person workshops, including the Watson Lecture at Caltech, which attracted over 500 attendees from neighboring communities and local high schools. The lecture video has been viewed thousands of times on YouTube, highlighting the significant impact this project has had on both the scientific community and the public.
